Much better than the canned stuff.  You'll love it.


Perpetually on the mo=
ve and constantly busy. 

On Oct 20, 2011, at 12:09 PM, Super Cyclonus <sup=
ercyclonus@...> wrote:

> Adam,
> 
> Well, I don't have Sandy's aweso=
me recipe for Chicken soup, I tend to
> cheat and buy it out of a can! :) B=
ut I do hope that you are feeling
> better soon. And don't worry, I am sure=
 the game came wait for a while
> longer. The land of make-believe should A=
LWAYS take a back-seat to the
> real one. :)
> 
> P.S. Sandy, I may have to=
 try the recipe myself :)
> 
> - Preston
> 
> On 10/20/11, Sandy <magicquar=
tz@...> wrote:
> > I hope you feel better soon. I just made a block b=
uster chicken soup from
> > scratch to bring to my friend's mom who was als=
o not feeling well. And if
> > you have someone to make it for you, here's =
what you do.
> >
> > Ingredients: One whole chicken, three to four onions, =
a handful of parsley,
> > five of six carrots, several stalks of celery, an=
d a pinch of salt,
> > according to your taste.
> >
> > Put the whole chick=
en in a large soup pot, and pour just enough water over
> > the chicken to =
cover it. Then add onions, carrots, celery and then season
> > with salt ac=
cording to your own taste. Start the soup on high until it
> > begins to bo=
il, then lower to a slow to steady simmer for two to three hours
> > or unt=
il the legs of the chicken are loose. * Just lift the chicken out of
> > th=
e pot with a pair of tongs and jiggle the legs* . Once the legs are
> > loo=
se, you're ready to take the meat and veggies out of the soup. First
> > di=
scard the parsley, which is only there for flavor, then in a sparate
> > mi=
xing bowl, you add the veggies and on a platter you put the chicken.
> > Al=
low meat and veggies to cool and then start by cutting the veggies into
> >=
 bite sized pieces and put them back into the broth of the soup. Then you
>=
 > take the chicken off the bones, discard skin, fat and bones, and shred t=
he
> > meat into bite sized pieces and put that back into the soup. Once th=
is is
> > done, turn off the heat and allow the soup to cool. Once it cools=
 down the
> > fat will rise to the top and it will solidify. When you're re=
ady to eat it,
> > just skim the top of the soup and remove the fat. Heat t=
o desired
> > temperature slowly and boil up your favorite pasta and most i=
mportantly,
> > ENJOY.
> >
> > This is our family recipe that comes straigh=
t from Florence, Italy. Trust
> > me, you'll love it.
> >
> > --- In nbwrpg=
@yahoogroups.com, "adamsafran" <adamsafran@...> wrote:
> >>

y for the lack of posting, running a fever and so I fear I won't
> >> be su=
per active until it passes. Thanks for understanding!
> >>

<html><body bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF"><div>Much better than the canned stuff. &nb=
sp;You'll love it.</div><div><br><br>Perpetually on the move and constantly=
 busy. </div><div><br>On Oct 20, 2011, at 12:09 PM, Super Cyclonus &lt=
;<a href=3D"mailto:supercyclonus@...">supercyclonus@...</a>>=
 wrote:<br><br></div><div></div><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div>




<span s=
tyle=3D"display:none"> </span>



    <div id=3D"ygrp-text">
      
  =
    
      <p>Adam,<br>
<br>
Well,  I don't have Sandy's awesome recipe for=
 Chicken soup, I tend to<br>
cheat and buy it out of a can! :) But I do hop=
e that you are feeling<br>
better soon. And don't worry, I am sure the game=
 came wait for a while<br>
longer. The land of make-believe should ALWAYS t=
ake a back-seat to the<br>
real one. :)<br>
<br>
P.S. Sandy, I may have to =
try the recipe myself :)<br>
<br>
- Preston<br>
<br>
On 10/20/11, Sandy &lt=
;<a href=3D"mailto:magicquartz%40yahoo.com"><a href=3D"mailto:magicquartz@y=
ahoo.com">magicquartz@...</a></a>> wrote:<br>
> I hope you feel=
 better soon.  I just made a block buster chicken soup from<br>
> scratc=
h to bring to my friend's mom who was also  not feeling well.  And if<br>
&=
gt; you have someone to make it for you, here's what you do.<br>
><br>
&=
gt; Ingredients:  One whole chicken, three to four onions, a handful of par=
sley,<br>
> five of six carrots, several stalks of celery, and a pinch o=
f salt,<br>
> according to your taste.<br>
><br>
> Put the whole c=
hicken in a large soup pot, and pour just enough water over<br>
> the ch=
icken to cover it.  Then add onions, carrots, celery and then season<br>
&g=
t; with salt according to your own taste.  Start the soup on high until it<=
br>
> begins to boil, then lower to a slow to steady simmer for two to t=
hree hours<br>
> or until the legs of the chicken are loose.  * Just lif=
t the chicken out of<br>
> the pot with a pair of tongs and jiggle the l=
egs* .  Once the legs are<br>
> loose, you're ready to take the meat and=
 veggies out of the soup.  First<br>
> discard the parsley, which is onl=
y there for flavor, then in a sparate<br>
> mixing bowl, you add the veg=
gies and on a platter you put the chicken.<br>
> Allow meat and veggies =
to cool and then start by cutting the veggies into<br>
> bite sized piec=
es and put them back into the broth of the soup.  Then you<br>
> take th=
e chicken off the bones, discard skin, fat and bones, and shred the<br>
&gt=
; meat into bite sized pieces and put that back into the soup.  Once this i=
s<br>
> done, turn off the heat and allow the soup to cool. Once it cool=
s down the<br>
> fat will rise to the top and it will solidify.  When yo=
u're ready to eat it,<br>
> just skim the top of the soup and remove the=
 fat.  Heat to desired<br>
> temperature slowly and boil up your favorit=
e pasta and most importantly,<br>
> ENJOY.<br>
><br>
> This is our=
 family recipe that comes straight from Florence, Italy.  Trust<br>
> me=
, you'll love it.<br>
